factors.name: High debt levels
factors.contents: High debt levels will remain a key credit consideration for several years.
factors.evidence: high debt levels will remain a key credit consideration for several years

factors.name: Debt reduction focus
factors.contents: Cash deployment will be almost exclusively focused on debt reduction for the next several years.
factors.evidence: Fitch expects cash deployment will be almost exclusively focused on debt reduction for the next several years.

factors.name: Sufficient liquidity for debt paydown
factors.contents: Sufficient FCF and excess liquidity to pay down maturing and callable debt over the next three years.
factors.evidence: Fitch estimates Boeing should have sufficient FCF and excess liquidity to pay down this debt while still maintaining higher liquidity that it has held in the past.

factors.name: High leverage metrics
factors.contents: Leverage metrics will remain high for the 'BBB-' rating until sometime in 2024.
factors.evidence: Leverage metrics (both EBITDA and FFO based) will remain high for the 'BBB-' rating (above 3.5x on a gross basis, or 2.0x-2.5x on a net basis) until sometime in 2024.

factors.name: Liquidity supports rating
factors.contents: Liquidity supports the current IG rating with commercial business recovering.
factors.evidence: With commercial business recovering, Boeing' liquidity supports the current IG rating.

factors.name: Positive cash flow outlook
factors.contents: Cash flow to turn positive in the next few quarters, leaving Boeing with a solid liquidity position.
factors.evidence: Fitch expects cash flow to turn positive in the next few quarters, leaving Boeing with a solid liquidity position.

factors.name: Inventory as liquidity tailwind
factors.contents: Substantial inventory of new aircraft should be a cash and liquidity tailwind in the next 18 months.
factors.evidence: The substantial inventory of new aircraft accumulated in the past two years should be a cash and liquidity tailwind in the next 18 months.

factors.name: Equity as financial flexibility
factors.contents: Equity remains another source of financial flexibility for the company.
factors.evidence: Equity remains another source of financial flexibility for the company.

factors.name: No public equity issuance
factors.contents: Boeing did not issue public equity to fund liquidity in 2020.
factors.evidence: Unlike many aviation companies in 2020, Boeing did not issue public equity to fund liquidity

factors.name: No material pension contributions expected
factors.contents: No material pension contributions expected in the next few years.
factors.evidence: Fitch does not expect Boeing to make material pension contributions in the next few years.

factors.name: Pension contributions satisfy requirements
factors.contents: Recent pension contributions should satisfy most required contributions for the next several years.
factors.evidence: These contributions should satisfy most required contributions for the next several years.

factors.name: Plan funded on ERISA basis
factors.contents: Pension plan was more than 100% funded on an ERISA basis at end of 2020.
factors.evidence: the plan was more than 100% funded on an ERISA basis.

factors.name: 2021 cash burn risk
factors.contents: 2021 FCF will be negative due to delays in 787 deliveries and China's MAX recertification.
factors.evidence: we now expect BA will burn $4 billion-$6 billion because of the delays in 787 deliveries and China's MAX recertification.

factors.name: Restructuring and orders support cash flow
factors.contents: 2021 underlying cash flow has been better-than-expected due to restructuring and new aircraft orders.
factors.evidence: Fitch believes 2021 underlying cash flow has been better-than-expected, mainly because of restructuring efforts and new aircraft orders.

factors.name: Cash flow headwinds
factors.contents: Headwinds include MAX concessions, facility inefficiencies, rising inventory, higher interest expense, and working capital investment.
factors.evidence: Headwinds include MAX concessions, inefficiencies at some of Boeing's aircraft facilities due to low production rates, rising inventory of undelivered 787's, higher interest expense, and some working capital investment to support to ramp up of MAX production in 2022.

factors.name: Cash flow tailwinds
factors.contents: Tailwinds include delivery of MAX and 787 planes, restructuring benefits, and order deposits.
factors.evidence: Tailwinds include the delivery of MAX and 787 planes out of inventory, restructuring benefits, and order deposits.

factors.name: Positive FCF forecast 2022
factors.contents: FCF will be positive in 2022 in the mid-single digits in base case forecast.
factors.evidence: Fitch expects FCF will be positive in 2022 in the mid-single digits in our base case forecast.

factors.name: Further FCF improvement forecast
factors.contents: Further improvements in FCF forecast for 2023 and 2024, but not to pre-2019 levels.
factors.evidence: Fitch forecasts further improvements in FCF in 2023 and 2024, but not to levels seen prior to 2019.

factors.name: Consolidated BCC treatment
factors.contents: Fitch looks at Boeing and BCC on a consolidated basis for credit analysis.
factors.evidence: Fitch looks at Boeing and BCC on a consolidated basis for several reasons.

factors.name: BCC strategic shift
factors.contents: BCC shifted focus from portfolio growth to facilitating third-party financing for customers.
factors.evidence: successful strategic shift to reduce BCC's emphasis on portfolio growth and increase focus on facilitating third-party financing for customers.

factors.name: BCC debt guarantee
factors.contents: Boeing fully guaranteed all of BCC's outstanding debt in early 2013.
factors.evidence: In early 2013, Boeing fully guaranteed all of BCC's outstanding debt

HP has access to its undrawn $4 billion senior unsecured revolving credit facility, which backs up its $6 billion CP program. Additionally, on May 29, 2020 the company entered into a 364-day revolving credit facility with $1 billion in aggregate lending commitments. HP had $613 million in CP borrowings at April 30, 2020.

factors.evidence: Walmart's strong liquidity profile is bolstered by its cash balance ($9 billion as of April 30, 2025) and by its revolvers totaling $15 billion, which partially backstop Walmart's commercial paper program. factors.name: Strong liquidity position
factors.contents: Large cash and marketable securities balance supports liquidity
factors.evidence: Amazon reported $49.3 billion in cash, cash equivalents, and marketable securities as of March 31, 2020, which combined with the company's undrawn $7 billion unsecured revolver due to mature in April 2021 , totals $56.3 billion in liquidity.

factors.name: Commercial paper program support
factors.contents: Commercial paper program supports working capital and M&A
factors.evidence: Fitch expects commercial paper usage to primarily support seasonal working capital swings but could also support M&A activity or other investments for longer-term growth initiatives.

factors.name: Finance lease usage
factors.contents: Finance leases used for infrastructure to preserve cash
factors.evidence: Amazon has chosen to enter into finance leases (formerly termed capital leases), generally with three to five year terms, for some of its infrastructure, particularly facilities supporting AWS, given its low cost of capital and desire to preserve cash for investment optionality.

factors.name: Finance lease capitalization
factors.contents: Finance leases capitalized at 4.0x annual operating expenses
factors.evidence: Per Fitch's criteria, the company's finance lease arrangements are capitalized at 4.0x annual operating expenses (including amortization and interest).

factors.name: Finance lease expense treatment
factors.contents: Finance lease expenses deducted from EBITDA and FCF, added to EBITDAR
factors.evidence: Finance lease amortization and interest expense, like operating lease expense, are now considered operating expenses by Fitch and are deducted from EBITDA and FCF; these expenses, which are expected to be around $11 billion in 2020 but decline several billion per year as capital leases roll off, would be added back in Fitch's EBITDAR calculation and added to Fitch's financing cash flow calculation.

factors.name: Leverage neutral note issuance
factors.contents: Proposed unsecured notes issuance expected to be leverage neutral over time
factors.evidence: the issuance is expected to be leverage neutral over time as existing finance leases roll off and are not replaced.

factors.name: Potential unsecured debt growth
factors.contents: Unsecured debt balance could grow to support growth initiatives
factors.evidence: Amazon's unsecured debt balance could grow modestly over time to support growth initiatives, though Amazon could use FCF to reduce debt as it has on occasion in the past.
